•

completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
• (4) At least 1 adult member of the household
must have training in and maintain a current
certification in first aid and cardiopulmonary
resuscitation from the American Heart
Association or the American Red Cross, or other
institution approved by the department.
One of three foster home files reviewed did not have current certification for
CPR/First Aid as required.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
• (c) A physical examination for each child
as follows, unless a greater frequency is
medically indicated:
• (ii) A physical examination every
14 months.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have a physical examination
completed within 14 months as required.

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or
parents and the foster parents in the
development of service plans to enable the
parent or parents and foster parents to
understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting
the agency in carrying out the plan. An agency
shall give a copy to and review the parent-
agency treatment plan with the parent or parents
and foster parents. The agency must inform the
parent or parents and foster parent that the
information in the parent-agency treatment plan
and any other information about the child and
the child's family is confidential.
Five of six foster care case files reviewed did not indicate that the plan was
developed with the parent/parents or foster parents to enable the
parent/parents/foster parents to understand the plan.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2025SIC0000396 Approved 04/02/2025 CAP Approved 4/28/25
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have the Updated Service Plan (USP)
completely timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

CPA Rule 400.12422 Foster care case record
• (3) The record must contain all the following
information:
• (e) Change of placement documentation
as required by R 400.12405.
One of six foster care case files reviewed did not document the change of

CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
• (1) An agency social service worker shall
complete a written adoptive evaluation within 90
days of the family signing an adoption
application and prior to approving a family for

One of three adoptive family files reviewed contained adoptive family evaluation
not completed within the 90 days of the signed application.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance:
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
Special investigation #2025SIC0000396 was initiated 2/14/2025, and the CAP was
approved on 4/28/2025. The agency was found in noncompliance with licensing
rule 400.12418 (5). This CAP is still in effect and not completed.
The agency submitted a CAP in response to the 2024 interim inspection. The
report was completed 9/6/2024 and the CAP was approved on 10/3/2024. The
CAP addressed 4 violations. There was improvement with two of the violations
that were cited in the 2024 interim inspection. However, during this licensing
period, 1 of the violations that were cited in the 2024 interim inspection and 1
violation in the special investigation report are repeats for this year indicating
additional corrective action planning is needed this year with the repeat violations.
Chief Administrator Assessment:
The Chief Administrator (CA) assessment identified areas of previously submitted
and approved CAP that were not successful, such as special investigation,
development of service plans and parent agency treatment plans. The CA
identified challenges with rule/policy compliance due to staff turnover, supervisors
carrying cases which neglected and impacted the opportunity for new workers to
transition into the agency. The CA explained when supervisors carried cases, staff
weekly supervision did not always occur, and it was not consistent. She reported
when supervisors were carrying cases, case management was being completed
but the information was not always documented correctly or timely. The CA
reported the current corrective action plan has been used as a guide and for
tracking. The CA reported the CAP is used in all of staff and individual team
meetings to keep the need before the staff and to address any ongoing concerns.
She said the division director reviews the CAP with strategies of improvement with
the managers at least monthly.
Financial Overview:
The agency’s certified independent auditor’s report dated September 30, 2024,
and 2023 and the agency annual financial budget report was reviewed. There
were no financial concerns identified.
Staff Interviews:
The staff interviewed feel supported by their coworkers, supervisors and
management. The staff discussed the impact of staff turnover and how it affects
their day-to-day routine as more work is added to their already large caseloads.
Their supervisors, and coworkers are always there to assist if the need arises. The
staff reported some of the support with training is put in place, but they would like

to see a stronger program applied to new workers when they return to the agency
from attending the CWTI training.
Description of Agency Walk Through:
The agency has adequate space and equipment to perform required job duties.
Files are stored securely and in a manner that provides unauthorized access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
